Hulk Vs. is so far the best animated film created by Marvel. Both short films are full of graphic violence, great animation, and the characters are played as they should be. Even the storylines are great in this DVD!

Hulk Vs. Wolverine: Logan is assigned to take down the monstrous Hulk as he tears apart the Canadian countryside. Or is it really the Hulk alone who is causing all the damage? Wolverine soon finds out that Sabretooth, Omega Red, Lady DeathStrike, and Deadpool have been hunting the Hulk for the Weapon X program and attempt to use the most powerful monster on the planet as a weapon. But Lady DeathStrike and the others have other plans.

Hulk Vs. Thor: Odin is asleep and it seems that all of Asgard's enemies have been defeated. But Loki has captured Bruce Banner and plans to unleash the Hulk and destroy Thor. But can Loki truelly control such a savage and powerful monster? For not even Thor nor any God has the strength or the power to stop the Hulk!

My addvice, buy this DVD set. If you are true fan of the core material of the comics, then this DVD is for you. However, beware it is extremely graphic and should not be seen by those under the age of 13. The bonous features are a great treat and plus we get a look at Thor: Tales Of Asgard. So, what are you waiting for? Buy now and enjoy!

Hulk vs. Thor

The world of Asgard which is protected by the All Father Odin. During the winter for one week, Odin goes into a slumber called the Odinsleep and at this point he's vulnerable, and Asgard plunges into war when his son Loki attacks his kingdom. The attacks are always thwarted by Thor, but this time Loki has added a being with immense strength to his ranks, a being that has brought Thor to his knees once before, The Incredible Hulk. -summary

Hulk Vs. is a two part movie by Marvel that features one big slugfest after the other starring the green goliath. Hulk vs. Thor is the first movie in the line up and although more story driven than the second movie. It's still an all out brawl of epic proportions as the Hulk takes on not only Thor but the entire Asgard kingdom. Throughout the years, Hulk and Thor have clashed several times and it has always been a highly anticipated battle from comic to comic. If one would really look at it, it always has been and always will be Marvel's main event, because it features the two most popular heavy hitters in the Marvel Universe.

If this movie was compared to any of their battles from the comics then it ranks somewhere in the bottom; but as a movie it has plenty of very entertaining moments. It takes very little time for the fist to start flying and the two mix up pretty viciously. Even though the movie is action oriented, the story and plot are very strong. The god of evil Loki, Thor's step brother, uses his power to bring Bruce Banner to Asgard and he manipulates the Hulk through magic to do his bidding. There's never a dull moment and during this short feature there's a small amount of character development to the point where a casual fan will not feel lost. The movie also ends on a good note and nothing is left unclear.

Hulk vs. Wolverine

Wolverine is called in to investigate the country side of Canada where the Hulk was said to have been causing mindless destruction. He comes upon a distraught Bruce Banner. After smacking him around a little, Banner becomes enraged and turns into the Hulk. From there Wolverine finds himself fighting for his life.-summary

Wolverine has tangled with the Hulk in most of his incarnations. This battle pays homage to their very first run-in that took place in The Incredible Hulk #181 back in 1974, except this battle does not feature the Wendigo. Hulk vs. Wolverine is considered the best of the two movies by many, and it's mainly because of the no holds barred, bloody, and brutal action. This is by far the most violent of the two movies, as Wolverine is very vicious here when digging his claws deep into the Hulk. This story also features very familiar and popular faces from Wolverine's rogue's gallery in the forms of Sabretooth, Deadpool, Lady Deathstrike, and Omega Red.

The animation is some of the best I seen from Marvel by the time this movie was released; but I do find it to be slightly inferior to DC's animated movies. The action scenes are very fast paced and almost everything is shown in full detail. The camera has its moments too and there are small comic book cover art homages paid during the Wolverine and Hulk fight that only a serious fan will catch. I didn't have many issues with the artwork except I thought Deadpool was way too scrawny, but I guess it was meant to add to his comedic side. The sound effects were very good as well. Hulk vs. Thor I think stood out in this area a little better. It was pretty cool hearing Hulk take those hammer shots from Thor.

The voice acting was spot on for the most part. Graham McTavish got too into his role as Loki and he delivered a fine performance. Steve Blum whom is also well known for voicing Spike Spiegel of Cowboy Bebop was very good as Wolverine, and Deadpool's comedic side was captured well by Nolan North.

I did enjoy both movies, however there was something that kept nagging me. Despite the Hulk supposedly being the star, he felt more like a side character or a plot device. He was only meant to push the plot during Hulk vs. Thor. While in Hulk vs. Wolverine, he could have actually been left out of that story altogether, and with a few adjustments, that could have been a full fledged Wolverine story because his background was explored, and it was his rogues gallery as the main antagonist.

Another thing that bothered me was that the Thor fight seemed a little too one sided at times. I know Hulk is very strong, but Thor's rogues gallery consists of some very powerful beings. Plus he has been able to do things I doubt Hulk could ever do; such as drive off the world devourer Galactus and kill a Celestial. Then again, it all depends on who the writers are and they seem to be very pro Hulk.

These are small gripes I doubt many would care about though. The two movies are still very entertaining, and will more than likely please fans of the characters. I find it hard to believe that an action fan will come away disappointed. The movie has an 82 minute run time. Recommended.

Two short films, one explosive movie!

Hulk vs Wolverine: Logan (Wolverine) is called in to a small town that the Hulk just ravaged in an effort to track down the beast and stop him for good. However, once the two meet, they go head-to-head and battle to the finish. Different phases of the fight trigger certain flashbacks for Wolverine and he remembers bits and pieces of how he came to be and his history with Weapon X (who also shows up).

This part of the movie is all-out-hey-bub-come-get-some craziness. Wolverine lets it rip and him and Hulk go at it like no ones business, definitely making this segment the more exciting of the two in terms of action. I mean, Hulk really smashes and showcases his raw power and strength and, Im telling you, theres no holding back.

Putting Wolverine up against Hulk was a smart move because here you got this guy whos tough as nails, has a healing factor, and has an adamantium skeletonand claws! that make him near invincible. On the I-can-take-some-serious-damage level, Wolverine is right up there.

I also appreciated how they had him slice into Hulk versus just having the two slug it out. Frankly, Wolverines punches against the Hulk wouldnt him take him far, if anywhere at all. Have him start cutting the Hulk with his clawsand with them being adamantium, they can do thatnow Hulk finds himself in some serious jeopardy if hes not careful.

Storywise, this one was the weaker of the two, but getting a brief overview of the Weapon X program and Wolverines creation is a plus for fans. Besides, Deadpool is in this and who doesnt love that?

Onto . . .

Hulk vs Thor: Loki transports Hulk to Asgard while the city is no longer under Odins protection thanks to his annual Odinsleep. By separating Bruce Banner from the Hulk, Loki removes the restraint on the Hulk and unleashes the green beast against the unsuspecting Asgardians. Thor steps in to stop the Hulk from breaking in and destroying the city. The two battle it out in the realm eternal and only one can be the victor.

Straight off, the storytelling of this one was much more complex than the Hulk vs Wolverine segment. I appreciated that and liked how Thor was dragged into this battle as opposed to him just trying to get back at Hulk for something or simply seeing who is the strongest.

Sticking Hulk in the realm of Asgard as opposed to having the story take place on Earth changes things up for those of us not used to Hulk fighting in that kind of arena. Throw some complex emotions and Hulks inner turmoil into the mix by way of honing in on Bruce Banner, and you got a good Hulk story.

This one focused more on Hulk in that regard whereas the other one seemed to focus more on Wolverine despite this movie titled as being Hulk-centric.

The battles on Asgard were almost as good as the Hulk vs Wolverine ones, but not as awe-inspiring. I did like, however, Hulk going up against multiple opponents in this as he took on the Asgardians.

The movie as a wholeI wish theyd do a live action version or something similar if they ever do a follow up to The Incredible Hulk. To have Hulk not just have the army on his tail but also other powerful superheroes would make for an exciting flick.

My one star rating is for the horribly one sided Hulk vs Thor.

Hulk vs Thor, as already mentioned by other reviewers, was obviously made by people with a total dislike for the Thunder God.

I love both Thor and the Hulk and have been following their encounters since I was a kid. The record of their fights is slightly inclined to Hulk's favor: lots of draws between the two, with 1 or 2 wins for Thor and 3 or 4 wins for Hulk; or something close to that.

Yet in this movie Thor is portrayed as a totally inferior and ineffective adversary against the Hulk.

And why is that? Just turn on the commentary feature of the film to hear the makers of the movie ridicule the Thor character (this has been mentioned by at least another reviewer of this movie).

I would have been equally disappointed if the Hulk character was the one depicted as badly as Thor was in this movie. As a fan of comics I expect DC, Marvel and the other companies to be aware of the respect they owe to their characters and to us the fans of those characters. In my book that means to portray them fairly and true to their imaginary attributes, qualities and weaknesses. And not to make that portrayal based on biases, personal likes/dislikes and whims of writers, directors or any others responsible for developing the plots or scripts.

This charade of a superheroes animation film is an affront to those of us who appreciate and value the fair depiction of the fictional characters whose publications we have cherished for so many years. The mockery of the Mighty Thor that is so evident in the story and so admittedly true in the makers' commentaries is something that Marvel should have not let happened.

Again I would have disliked this film just as much if the despising and disrespect had been directed against the Hulk. No superhero character should be disrespected like this.

Pretty straight forward, plot light action fodder stories, one pits a pre-X-Men Wolverine against both the Hulk & the clawed one's particular rogue's gallery (which includes such fan favorites as Deadpool and Sabertooth), the other has a completely savage Banner-less Hulk being used by Loki to attack Thor & Asgard during the Odinsleep (when Odin the All-Father, AKA: Thor & Loki's dad, rests, leaving Asgard more vulnerable to attack).

In the end the Wolverine segment is the stronger of the two, much stronger perhaps because screenwriters & frequent partners in crime Craig Kyle & Chris Yost are at heart more X-Men fans - and especially appear to be more Wolverine fans - and appear to be more fans of Hulk than Thor (which makes it strange that "Avengers: Earth's Mightiest Heroes" for which Yost was the show-runner a few years later, treated both characters more equally than this pathetic drivel), though one should probably not discount corporate shenanigans (the same shenanigans that resulted in Hulk & Iron Man having big supporting roles in "Next Avengers" while Thor got completely vilified as well as being reduced to a cameo). The Wolverine segment gives fans of this extremely overrated character what they expect - a better adaptation of his origin than the god awful 2009 film, as well as very hard hitting action, the kind Wolverine has never been able to have in past animated efforts for obvious reasons. The voice acting all around is very good - Steve Blum is an excellent Wolverine (he even sounds a little bit like Cal Dodd from the 90s series) and Nolan North is absolutely hilarious as Deadpool, the merc with a mouth (how North got miscast as Cyclops on "Wolverine & the X-Men" remains a mystery).

The Thor segment, however, is nothing puerile garbage designed to be lowest common denominator masturbation for the Hulk fans as Hulk subjects Thor to a laughably humiliating beat down & then proceeds to batter Asgard to its knees, courtesy of Loki's machinations. Good voice actors - Graham McTavish as Loki steals every scene he's in - are wasted on poor writing that fails to invest the audience in the plight of its characters because the characters clearly aren't as important as Hulk's rampage. Not even Bruce Banner getting a glimpse of a peaceful ending resonates the way it should. Where the Wolverine segment featured an eye rollingly laughable shot of Wolverine bringing the equally overrated Hulk to his knees after a few chest slashes, here Thor is reduced to a green rookie who just stands around like an idiot allowing the Hulk to beat the crap out of him, ignoring the centuries of combat experience, just so the Hulk, who's really not even that interesting of a character no matter who's writing him, can look good and Hulk fans can squeal like children while Thor fans are left with nothing. On top of that, the animation in the Thor segment is absolutely hideous - the character designs are ugly and clunky as Hell, with Thor being the ugliest and clunkiest of all (his love interests, steadfast Sif and evil Amora, don't exactly live up to their comic book beauty either), and the designs don't animate well, which makes the already poor quality fight scenes look even more ridiculous. Yeah, the Wolverine segment also features highly stylized designs but they actually work for the more grounded hard edged thriller that they set out to be, while the stylized designs of the Thor segment don't work at all. Thor & his fellow Asgardians would receive far better designs on "Earth's Mightiest Heroes" and even in "Tales of Asgard" where Thor, Loki, Sif & Amora are mere teenagers.

"Hulk Vs." consists of two films featuring "Hulk vs. Thor" and "Hulk vs. Wolverine."  As you can imagine, these two confrontations strike very different tones.

The action begins with "Hulk vs. Thor" and it sets the bar quite high. Odin goes into hibernation every winter to regain his strength for a week, during which time Asgard's enemies attack. Thor (Matthew Wolf, reprising his role from "Thor: Tales of Asgard") along with the Einherjar rally to defend Asgard each year.  For accomplished fighters like the Asgardian warriors, they consider the seasonal raids to be a fun exercise, making a mockery of their enemy's efforts.

Loki (Graham McTavish) is not happy about this state of affairs and crafts a plan: Using the Enchantress' (Kari Wahlgren) sorcery, he captures Bruce Banner (Bryce Johnson), turns him into the Hulk (Fred Tatasciore), and then extracts Banner's soul.  Without the calming influence of Banner, the Enchantress turns the Hulk into Loki's puppet, making him the ultimate killing machine.  Ignoring Banner's pleas, Loki sends the remote-controlled Hulk into Asgard.

The Hulk makes short work of just about everybody, including Thor. When Thor manages to wrest control of the Hulk away from Loki, the Hulk goes berserk and nearly beats Thor to death. He is saved from death's door by the Enchantress, who has a crush on Thor and betrays Loki by explaining his plot.  When Thor confronts Loki about his nefarious plans, he discovers Banner dead, murdered by Loki in a fit of pique. Banner's death in Asgard condemns his soul to Hel, one the nine Asgardian realms.

Thor convinces Loki that if they don't reunite Banner's soul with the Hulk he will destroy all of Asgard.  Loki commits his forces to delay the Hulk while he and Thor descend to Hel to retrieve Banner's soul.  But the Queen of Hel, Hela (Janyse Jaud) is in no mood to release any souls from her embrace.

This is where "Hulk vs. Thor" really does an excellent job of fleshing out Bruce Banner, who is normally just an irritating side character whining about getting angry.  Unlike the other souls tortured in Hell, Banner has finally found peace, living a fantasy life with Betty Ross (Nicole Oliver) and even raising a child. In short, Banner doesn't want to be reunited with the Hulk and it's hard to blame him.

Conversely, "Hulk vs. Wolverine" is just a bunch of Weapon X characters slicing each other up, with the Hulk occasionally in the middle. There's cigar-chomping, "bub"-spouting Wolverine (Steven Blum), grim Russian Omega Red (Colni Murdock), the angry Lady Deathstrike (Janyse Jaud), the prickly Sabretooth (Mark Acheson), and joke-machine Deadpool (Nolan North).  Wolverine's out to catch the Hulk and the Weapon X team is out to catch Wolverine at the behest of mad professor Thornton (Tom Kane).

Unlike "Hulk vs. Thor," "Hulk vs. Wolverine" features a wimpy Banner whom everyone looks down on, including Wolverine.  His only purpose is to be goaded into turning into the Hulk, which ignores a major facet of the Hulk persona.

Throughout "Hulk vs. Wolverine" are intermittent flashbacks to Wolverine's origin, which is peculiar because it shifts the focus away from the Hulk.  On the plus side, the film lets Wolverine really let loose with his claws, slicing off limbs and stabbing people in great gouts of bloody gore.  Still, the attacks are meaningless - the X factor healing ability of the entire Weapon X team means such wounds are temporary at most. Deadpool is the sole standout if only because he makes light of the absurdity of a top secret facility populated with nobody but killer mutants.

As the titular character, only "Hulk vs. Thor" gives the big green guy his due.  The first installment is basically "Wolverine vs. Hulk," which is fine if you're a Wolverine fan but if you're a Hulk fan, not so much.  It's enough to make Hulk fans angry...and you wouldn't like them when they're angry.

Actually, that`s putting it mildly. It this DVD were simply a waste of time I`d still give it 2 stars. The problem being that the Wolverine vs. Hulk episode is also offensive to Marvel fans of every age (the critics who gave positive Amazon-ratings notwithstanding, apparently.) While certain events in Wolverine`s history are depicted (Wolverine`s debut in The Incredible Hulk 181, as well as elements of Barry Windsor Smith`s excellent Weapon X -storyline from Marvel Comics Presents), nothing in Hulk vs. Wolverine is presented in a compelling manner. Apart from the Hulk`s rescue of two innocent bystanders during his initial confrontation with the Weapon X -squad, neither of the two protagonists, arguably two of the most tragic and complex characters in Marvel-lore, are presented as heroic beings - the Hulk merely smashes and roars, while Wolverine merely slices and snarls his way through this ordeal of a movie.

The animation is fine, but the violence is horribly graphic, rendering this feature unsuitable for a younger audience, while older viewers should feel offended by the lack of a decent plot and the non-existent characterization. The villains of the piece are merely `edgy`, but there`s no backstory to make any of them interesting. In the comics, Deadpool is much more than simply a wisecracking, guns and knives -wielding mercenary. I`m not entirely sure of his backstory, but the man was horribly disfigured during an experiment, which led to him becoming slightly unhinged. Lady Deathstrike traded her humanity for cybertech enhancements in order to gain revenge on Wolverine, whose mere existence she believed brought shame on her family. It would have been so easy to add some emotional drive to the movie`s narrative and many battles by referencing or even depicting said events.

In conclusion, I`d like to state that the movie left me, a longtime reader of Marvel Comics, questioning the appeal of characters created for the purpose of generating a never-ending stream of violent imagery. But no, it`s the makers of this misguided movie that decided to desregard everything that makes Hulk and Wolverine timeless, compelling characters worthy of the huge following they have amassed in the years since their creation. They deserve better, as did this this movie`s audience.

It takes a lot for an animated comic book series to impress me.  I've loved the animated Batman films, so I decided to take a venture into the animated Marvel universe.  Needless to say, I wasn't blown away by this blu-ray.  Let me break it down for you:

Hulk Vs. Thor- being a huuuge Thor fan, I feel like this didn't do justice to Asgard.  It tried to bring Simonson's and Kirby's work to life, but the result was too hokey for me.  Thor is best when subtle and powerful, instead of loud and ungraceful.  They nearly got there for me, but its a really tough balance.  The tone would have been better for kids.  I can't complain about the action or the actual Hulk.  The story was well done, and I enjoyed the fanboy nods.  My only dissapointment was that the tone didn't quite align with the story.

Hulk Vs. Wolverine- I actually enjoyed this one more, since it attempted to be more badass.  My first of two complaints was that it danced between kiddy and brutal too much.  The curseword-hiding dopey jokes do not match ultraviolence with blood at all.  Secondly, I praised the attempt to adapt Windsor-Smith's origin of Wolverine, but it should have been done separately.  That series is very dark and eerie, and it deserved it's standalone separate adaptation.  Cramming it into this movie didn't quite work for me because it was rushed, and it didn't fit witht the whole of the film.

Together these films aren't bad, I just won't be watching them again and again.  They mostly consist of great ideas, with scattered efforts.  To sum it up its all over the place.  The animation company did a mediocre job, really.  They should have gone with the full anime treatment, instead of an overseas company trying to mimic American animation.  There are a couple moments that are shoddy.  Don't worry though, because you will be entertained, but I doubt you will be totally impressed.  Watch Batman: Gotham Knight if you want to be blown away with modern comic book animation.

Comic companies have had a recent Renaissance with their animated properties by expanding into the direct to DVD market.  DC has been leading the pack in this endeavor, but Marvel has been slowly catching up.

This release gives you two 40-minute movies of the Hulk teaming-up (or fighting) with Thor and Wolverine.  Now, many people complained about the lack of action in Ang Lee's Hulk movie, but these flicks more than make up for that here.  Perhaps a bit too much.  The Wolverine part is very action-driven to the point it feels more like part of a story rather than a complete one.  This DVD was also ill-timed in its release as the short-lived Wolverine and the X-Men cartoon had a Hulk appearance at roughly the same time (although it's not quite as adult in tone).  The Thor story, though, fares a bit better and is a little more well-developed in comparison.  The only major complaint I have there is that Banner is drawn with these insane jowls that just droop.

Overall, both segments were entertaining and worth at least a watch.  I don't know how many repeated viewings it will be worth (I haven't been "dying" to see it again) but that will depend on the viewer.  If you are a big Deadpool fan, this is pretty much his animated debut, so it has that going for it.

Earlier reviews went over the storylines and the MARVEL universe in-depth, so I'll just add that as only an occasional frequenter to the MARVEL universe and comic book stuff in general, I liked this Blu-Ray disc. I didn't realize the effort and time they put into the different voice inflections, the physical effort to voice the characters, etc.

The Blu-Ray disc came through very nicely on my 720p plasma TV and Sony 460 BR player.  The menu is a bit confusing as it doesn't appear to resume play if you stop the movie and I never figured out how to use the BOOKMARKS function, assuming it works.  The BR disc takes a bit longer to load but these are minor quibbles.

What would have been a great addition for the EXTRAS would have been some of the 1960's cartoon shorts that you see on YouTube and might now be available on DVD's.  I remember the old "THOR" cartoons because of the opening jingle.  They should have put some of those on the BR disc, re-digitalized and upconverted to make it look nice.  There have been 2 "HULK" cartoons since the 1980's but they've made the rounds on TV and reruns and I think the older fans and the newer ones would have appreciated those 1960's cartoons that came out only a few years after Stan Lee and MARVEL had hit the ground running.

The length of the 2 movies is fine, but don't expect much in the way of character development or in-depth personality analysis of the characters.  Both episodes get into the action without much delay so if that is your game, you won't be disappointed.  No waiting around for 15 or 20 or 30 minutes as is sometimes the case with a feature-length movie.

Let's hope for more of these BR discs with the MARVEL characters instead of variations of the characters when they are younger or from alternate universe settings.  And I can't think of a better addition to the EXTRAS than some of those cartoons of yesteryear, which take up little space on the disc and to which MARVEL already owns the rights and should be able to add to the BR disc at minimal cost.

If you love the Hulk Smash, then this dvd is for you.  Hulk Vs. is a compilation of two animated short films, Hulk vs. Wolverine and Hulk vs. Thor. The first: Hulk vs. Wolverine was created to feature the character of Deadpool and generate hype for the new Wolverine and the X-men TV series, (which is now in its second season and doing rather well).  Hulk vs. Thor introduces audiences to Thor and his world, designed to build up interest in Marvels upcoming Thor live-action film.

Hulk vs. Wolverine features Logan's original comic debut, where he's sent by the government to bring down the Hulk.  Our two heroes duke it out for awhile before being captured by Weapon X.  We're introduced to Wolverine's past and his villains,\ (Sabretooth, Lady Deathstrike, Omega Red, and Deadpool).  The script really showcases Deadpool as a comedic highlight; the movie is worth watching for him alone.  Packed with tons of nicely choreographed action and a stunningly well-cast Wolverine, Hulk Vs. Wolverine is an excellent watch for any X-men or Hulk fan.

Hulk vs. Thor does a fine job of introducing the realm of Asgard and its heroes.  Loki, the God of Mischief, captures Bruce Banner and sends the rampaging Hulk to kill Thor.  Thor and all of Asgard throw themselves against the Hulk, but it'll take even more than Mijolnir's Hammer to stop this raging green beast.  If you get tired of really repetitive action and a lot of screaming "RAARGH!" every time someone gets hit, this movie is not for you.  Some more fight choreography would have done wonders here.  But if you're up for half an hour of Hulk going head to head with Asgard, (it fittingly reminded me of Minas Tirith from Lord of the Rings), then you'll get an eyeful.  Hulk vs. Thor serves its purpose of introducing Thor's characters and his world, but it just gets a little too long and a little too ridiculous.  The "eye-roll" moments are rather high here, what with lines like "but if the mighty Thor fails, what hope is there for Asgard?"  I recommend it for the fact that it sets up Planet Hulk extremely well.

I continue to love the Marvel animated movies and I'm happy the success of the Marvel live action hasn't undercut the animate stuff.  While the television shows can be doggy (Wolverine and the X-Men is so-so) the movies clearly guided by fans of the source material.  In the case of Hulk Vs you get two great stories drawn from the comics. Not direct retelling, but instead stories inspired by the comics in real and meaningful ways.  The clash between Wolverine and Hulk will please fans of both characters and the Thor/Hulk battle brings to mind Jack Kirby levels of Marvel magic.  If you are fan, you will love it, if you are not a fan, you should try it.

Hulk Vs is actually two separate animated movies, pitting the Hulk against the thunder god Thor and the mutant Wolverine. The flimsy-but-earnest circumstances that set up the heroes' conflict with the Hulk in both stories reminded me of the episodic one-off stories that got me hooked on comics as a child. They are not ambitious or pretentious. If you need to know more about the characters than what can be said in a few sentences, this movie will only frustrate you. Everyone else should sit back and enjoy. I liked both stories, but the one starring Wolverine was executed a little bit better. It was nice and violent, and did a great job of acknowledging Wolverine's history including a nod to Herb Trimpe's original yellow and blue uniform design and Barry Windsor-Smith's classic Wolverine: Weapon X story. There were great cartoon versions of Sabertooth, Deadpool, and Omega Red... and yeah, Hulk was in it, too. I was pleasantly surprised with how much they were able to fit comfortably into the Wolverine story. The Thor story tried to do the same thing but was a lot more awkward. I thought both stories had a great sense of history without being bogged down by it. A nice blend of silver age writing and modern age animation and action (rated pg-13 for violence, including Wolverine drawing blood repeatedly).

Two great short stories in one pack; great value for the money.  Each story is different and separate; Fred Tatasciore as the Hulk is very good, as he was in each of the Avengers movies.  The violence is much more graphic than your standard saturday-morning cartoon fare, especially Wolverine's.  I would not recommend that one for anyone under 13, but the Thor story is ok down to 10 year-olds.  I was especially impressed with the rendition of Thor and the Asgardians; good voice acting all around, and the drama was even to the point of being epic; it really had a good level of intensity.

I've watched several of the recent Marvel animated movies (Ultimate Avengers 1 & 2, Next Avengers, Doctor Strange, Invincible Iron Man) and this was by far the best. This was basically because I was more familiar with Wolverine's back story than I was of Thor.  In any case this Blu-ray gets top marks.  Here are my thoughts;

Pros

+ Decent adult scenes of animated violence and blood.  Especially on Hulk vs. Wolverine.

+ Interesting (although somewhat predictable) storylines.

+ Nice behind the scenes "making of" extras.

+ Brilliant musical score by Guy Michelmore (he's scored most of the other recent Marvel animated features as well).

+ Amazing voice acting cast. Deadpool in particular was brought to life extremely well in this feature.

Cons

- A bit short, even with 2 stories.

- Not as enjoyable if you're not entirely familiar with all the characters in the Marvel Universe.  I had this problem with the Hulk vs. Thor portion of the story.

- Somewhat unbelievable that The Hulk can best Thor, who is a god.  Yes I understand it's a comic book setting but it still seems a bit unrealistic, if that's possible.

All in all an excellent animated film.  I rarely purchased Blu-ray discs immediately when they're released but this one got my money.  I just wish the total playtime would have been a little bit longer.  If you love the Hulk, Wolverine or Thor, this is a must have DVD.

This being my first animated, comic-inspired movie, I was leery.  Being a hardcore comic fan, I almost expected to be disappointed.  After watching Hulk Vs., however, I can say that I'm a fan.

Battle #1: HULK vs THOR (and friends)
Clearly based on the original Avengers storyline, this is a story of Asgard in danger.  Odin is asleep, and it's up to Thor and his soldiers to protect their land.  His brother Loki, desperate for control, seeks to attack by putting a spell on the Hulk and turning him loose.  The action is tense and exciting.  Watching Hulk tear through Asgard, and beating Thor to a pulp is awesome.  Seeing him palm people by their heads, necks, and legs, throwing them like ragdolls, is hilarious.  Have no fear!  Without ruining the ending, it's safe to say that the story ends up as most Marvel storylines.

With this story, I have a problem.  Hulk could not beat Thor.  It's just unreal.  Even the most cursory knowledge of Marvel superheroes would tell someone that.  Thor was literally created by Stan Lee as an answer to the near omnipotence of Hulk.  He's a demigod for goodness sakes!  Overall, however, the storyline for this one is fairly well developed, the action is awesome, and the resolution is near perfection.

Battle #2: Hulk vs. Wolverine (and friends)
Let's see... a massive free-for-all inside the Weapon X compound where Hulk is the proverbial bull in a China shop headlines the story.  Battling Wolverine is bad enough, but add in Deadpool, Lady Deathstrike, Omega Red, and Sabertooth and you have a serious battle royal.  At one point there is a great flashback to the Weapon X series, and issue #181, that brought us all the most awesome of all X-Men characters: Wolverine.

Deadpool's wise-cracking steals every scene, absolutely hilarious.  The story really isn't all that developed; it's just an excuse to have a vicious, bloody battle for 30 minutes.  Not that I'm complaining.

With incredible animation, superb story-telling, perfect voiceovers, and just HEAPS of action, this double-header is the quintessential reason why people become comic book fans.  Bravo Marvel!

Well not really being that into comic books and their characters (apart from the live action adaptations) I didn't really have high expectations of this, but I must say I genuinely enjoyed it. I have only managed to catch Hulk vs. Wolverine so far, but I will add my two cents in regards to Hulk vs. Thor when I've viewed that.

Hulk vs. Wolverine had a runtime by my calculations of around 37 minutes, so I really wasn't going to get a genuine plot or that much character depth. Well the story starts with X-Man, Wolverine being called into a remote and snowy location in which a small town has fell victim to the wrath of what the Americans call the Hulk. Wolverine must stop the Hulk before he finds another small town, but little does Wolverine know, all is not what it seems and Wolverine finds himself being re-united with his creator and some of his biggest enemies including Sabre tooth and Lady Death strike.

The overall tone of the piece is simply the violence of it all; there's no real dialogue that has any relevance and the plot is very basic even for an animation this short on time. I guess this is something definitely and primarily aimed at the types of people who have read the comics for years and have been begging for this to happen for twice as long. Who am I to know, maybe it's already happened in paper form and Marvel just took the decision to animate it for a new audience. Either way it's entertaining as hell.

"Hulk Vs." (awkward title, isn't it?) is actually a double-feature DVD sporting two short animated features: a thirty-some minute "Hulk Vs. Wolverine" story and a forty-some minute "Hulk Vs. Thor" piece.  Both are well animated and very heavy on action.  However, we also get some effective dialogue and characterization from each of the stories, as well as some imaginative scenarios.  I would have bought the two-disc edition of "Hulk Vs." if I knew it existed at the time of my purchase, as I tend to enjoy the documentaries and other generous extras included with such offerings, but even my single-disc version includes a handful of extra features, including audio commentaries on both films and previews of upcoming Marvel projects.  While I wouldn't say "rush out and get this right now", this is nevertheless an entertaining little treat for comics fans.

Hulk, his essence being that of always having a mad on, has had repeated run-ins with several of the other Marvel characters. There's his classic battles with the Thing, but Ben Grimm's not in here so let's put that aside. While I don't really recall the Hulk having much of a rivalry with Thor, Wolverine is another matter. Wolverine made his debut in the Hulk's comic book (issue #181) and these two have had a history since then, most of it not lovey-dovey. HULK VS. WOLVERINE and HULK VS. THOR are companion pieces - two short animated direct-to-dvd films, respectively 37 minutes and 45 minutes long - and are showcases not for intricate plotting and exposition but for meaty, hard-hitting, down-and-dirty fighty fights.

So Wolverine is the best there is at what he does, and here what Wolverine does best is get the Canuck pounded out of him. As HULK VS. WOLVERINE takes place, Logan is still a ways away from his stint with the X-Men. Here, he's still under orders from Department H, which sends him to investigate a creature which has crossed into Canada and annihilated a tiny town. And this sets up the first meet between Wolverine and the Hulk, as they face off in the Canadian wilds. The tussle follows its logical course, with the Hulk mostly getting the better licks in. I'd never seen Wolverine go painfully airborne so many times, at the behest of the Hulk's mighty haymakers. But then their fun bag of hurt is interrupted by Logan's old pals from the Weapon X program...

There is some serious violence featured in both HULK VS. WOLVERINE and HULK VS. THOR, and both films are most definitely NOT recommended for the young kids. In VS. WOLVERINE, with its free-for-all monster vs. monsters theme (even Logan doesn't come off as so noble) and with just about every character endowed with a healing factor, the storytellers are able to cut loose with the extremely brutal action sequences. Arms get ripped off or sliced off. People get gutted. And Logan calls everyone "Bub," except for Bruce Banner, whom he calls "Weepy." But it's cool that ferocious, remorseless fighters like Wolverine and the Hulk aren't restrained to PG-rated patty cake stuff.

Happy fun time for Wolverine fans as he's featured heavily in this one, his origins getting a good once over and with particular focus on his involvement with Weapon X. This story is set not too far removed from those days, and so what we get is a Logan who's even more hardcore than he is with the X-Men. Check out the way he induces Banner's transformation into the Hulk.

It's pretty neat seeing the other messed-up characters from Weapon X. Lady Deathstrike is as formidable as I remember her, while the merrily insane, scene-stealing Deadpool absolutely brings down the house with his hilarious one-liners. The levity he injects into this very grim movie is most welcome. And, by the way, do yourself a favor and stick around for a brief but funny post-end credits sequence.

Segueing now to Norse mythology. Apparently, it's all about Odin the All-Father. Odin's power is what safeguards Asgard, the Realm Eternal and home to the Norse gods. Except that once a winter the All-Father must rest, must spend a cycle of time in Odinsleep. At this time Asgard is at its most vulnerable, a most inauspicious time for its warriors, most especially when a rampaging Hulk shows up. It's all a plan of Loki's, of course, the god of mischief and the Thor-scorned Enchantress working dark enchantments to separate Bruce Banner from his always cheesed off alter ego. This division renders the Hulk at his most mindless and savage, become pure rage incarnate, and he makes short work of the pantheon of Norse gods.

Here's one example of these two films working in harmony, balancing each other. While VS. WOLVERINE feels gritty and dark, VS. THOR, even at only 45 minutes, has an epic tone. Gods are featured here, and frost giants, valkyries, the Warriors Three, the enchanted hammer Mjolnir, and the rainbow bridge, so immediately the story feels larger than life, but then factor in too the widescreen scenery and the bright colors. And, above all else, Thor, the god of thunder, who is so noble I feel like I should hate on him on principle. The Hulk goes thru Asgard's protectors as violently and easily as chimichangas go thru my dyspeptic grandmother. And, yes, the Hulk also batters Thor into pancake, in fact punches him thru a mountain. Thor is clearly worried about the Hulk ("This is no immortal evil that we face now. The Hulk has come to Asgard."). It's pretty intense, seeing the god of thunder being pummeled this badly, and I reiterate what's said in the audio commentary: "It says something, when a god... is afraid of you."

The resolution, of course, is easy to figure out, but I like that Bruce Banner wants no part of it. While I dig the Hulk, I'm not a fan of Bruce Banner. Note that in these two short films, he doesn't come away in a flattering light, presented as this tormented dude all weepy and sniveling. Anyway, if you've ever enjoyed Jack Kirby and Walt Simonson's takes on Thor and Asgard, then HULK VS. THOR'll put a grin on your mug.

This is a two disc package. Disc one has the HULK VS. WOLVERINE short animated film and the following special features: two audio commentaries (one by producer/co-writer Craig Kyle & co-writer Chris Yost, the other by supervising director/producer Frank Paur and storyboard artists Kevin Altieri & story Butch Lukic); "This Is Gonna Hurt" - the 20-minute-long Making Of HULK VS. WOLVERINE; Fan Frenzy: 2008 Comic Con - a Q & A panel with cast & crew (8 minutes long); and a first look at the television animated series WOLVERINE & X-MEN.

Disc two has the HULK VS. THOR short animated film and the following special features: two audio commentaries (one by Craig Kyle & Chris Yost, the other by Frank Paur, director Sam Lui & colorist James Peters); "Of Gods And Monsters" - the 18-minute-long Making Of HULK VS. THOR; Jack Kirby + Thor - various folks talk about artist Jack Kirby's influence on the look and feel of Thor; and a first look at the upcoming THOR: TALES OF ASGARD (about Thor when he was a youth).

I actually think that having these short running times was a good thing. HULK VS. WOLVERINE and VS. THOR are more impactful, get their plots rapidly moving, and benefits from a lack of dead spots. The voice acting is really good and the animation is terrific and fitting for each respective film: the rough-and-tumble grit of HULK VS. WOLVERINE, the archaic majesty and might versus might of HULK VS. THOR. In any case, both moods succeed in drawing you in. And, if you're like me, you'll end up in Blissville as the Hulk resentfully smashes about him like the world is one huge Whack-a-Mole, Wolverine unleashes his claws to do some serious damage, and Thor keeps on talking funny. I say to thee, awesomeness!!

While Marvel's intent here is pretty obvious (capitalize on the popularity of the last Hulk movie while simultaneously promoting their upcoming Wolverine and Thor movies), unlike some of their other direct-to-DVD animated releases, this one is actually good.  Scratch that, it's awesome.  The movie is really two separate movies, in which the Hulk goes up against Thor and Wolverine.  While the stories are fairly inaccurate as far as official comic book canon is concerned (to be expected), what makes these special is that the characterization is fantastic.  Indeed, both movies end up being more about Thor and the Asgardians and Wolverine and Weapon X than about the Hulk.  The Hulk is the focus of the stories, but its the other characters that really carry it.  There are also great little visual references to classic Marvel comics throughout.  My only real criticism is that I didn't like the voice-casting for Thor and Loki.  I think it might have been better had those actors had the reverse roles.  This isn't so with the Wolverine movie, though.  The casting there is perfect, especially Deadpool, who steals the show.

Overall, this is a fun movie, and if you're a comic book fan, it's even better.  The stories are simple but fun, the action is exciting (and far more violent than one would expect -the PG rating is well-deserved) and the animation is strong (it could have been a little better, but it's certainly better than what you get on TV).  By far, this is the best animated Marvel movie I've seen yet.

I had seen lots of trailers for this DVD on-line from Marvel and it looked great, so I was anxious to see it.  On viewing, I had mixed feelings.  The animation is good quality and looks fabulous on Blu-Ray, especially Asgard.  On the other hand, the two stories are so predictable that you could write them before you open the box.  I wasn't expecting it to be an Oscar winner, but I did expect it to be a DVD I would want to watch more than once.

The Marvel animated films from Lion's Gate have been pretty good so far, but Hulk VS is by far the best yet. Instead of just one feature-length flick, Hulk VS is two different animated films that total to be about 80 minutes in length, in which the Hulk takes on two different Marvel icons. Hulk VS Wolverine finds the Hulk rampaging through Canada and getting the attention of a pre-X-Men Wolverine and Department H. Wolverine's bloody battle with the Hulk results in running into Wolvie's old Weapon X cohorts (Sabretooth, Deathstrike, Omega Red, and Deadpool), and then things really get interesting. The second film, Hulk VS Thor, finds Thor's evil brother Loki seeking to take control of the Hulk for his own purposes in destroying Asgard, but naturally, things don't work out too well. While Hulk VS Wolverine is definitely the better of the two, Hulk VS as a whole is a blast that is compelling and fun from start to finish. There's plenty of odes to Marvel mythology peppered throughout the film, and there's great voice work as well. The only drawback of Hulk VS is that the animation may not be everyone's cup of tea, and the film is definitely too violent for younger viewers (who would be better off sticking with Next Avengers), but for the rest of us, Hulk VS is a treat. All in all, Hulk VS is the best Marvel animation to see the light of day yet, and if you're a Hulk fan, this is a must have.

I'm a big fan of animated movies. Disney, Japanese anime, justice league, batman animated series and the previous marvel dvd movies. All of them have high points and low points, the biggest concern is whether you are buying a hit or a miss. For $14, buy the special edition and get the two movies combined. If you aren't wanting both movies, or if the price goes up for some reason, stick with Hulk vs. Wolverine. This movie will shock you for as much as it shows. Normally, you barely get to see blood during fight scenes. This movies shows blood, people getting their arms cut off, people getting stabbed, cut down shot, etc. They use adult language and adult humor. I can highly recommend this product, as it gives a whole lot to the audience that they weren't probably expecting. The Hulk vs. Thor, not so great.

While I enjoyed the previous animated features from Marvel (Ultimate Avengers 1 & 2), I was not overly excited by the animation used in those films. They were a bit cheap-looking, and could have been so much more.

Well, it looks like Marvel realized that, and they've stepped it up a bit. Both mini-features in "Hulk VS" are well-animated, and pull no punches when it comes to blood, violence, and fine details. Anything with the Hulk and Wolverine in it should be violent, and bloody... and this is. Kids should probably not get to see this one until they're in their teens.

The Wolverine film is less Hulk and more Weapon X, but that's a good thing. All characters a represented well in this story. There are lots of background details for fans (Did you see X-23 in there?) and a lot of excitement. Voice work is excellent; Especially for Wolverine and Deadpool. The script is intelligent and not dumbed-down for a kid audience. My only complaints are that they don't give the casual viewer any idea WHEN this occurred in Wolverine's history, and the ending is pretty abrupt (though you should stick around after the credits to see the outcome).

The Thor feature was true to the comics, and really followed the Asgardian tales from Marvel quite well... But I've always had a problem with voice casting for Asgardians. Why do they always cast people who do British English (or faux-British) accents to portray the Asgardians? They aren't the gods of the U.K.! They're the NORSE gods, and as such should probably have Norse accents (and yes, I realize they're still speaking English, which is also just nonsensical, but I chalk that up to magic; They're speaking ancient Norse, but are understood by the listener, whatever their language, due to their Asgardian/godly nature).  Seriously-- Why does Loki sound like the British god of Mischief, instead of the Norse god of Mischief? Why does Thor sound like an Englishman who has lived in the United States for 40 years, rather than sounding like a Nordic god?

Seriously, Marvel-- This is simple. They are NORSE. They have more in common with the Swedish Chef than the cast of Fawlty Towers. Is that so hard to grasp, that you'd fail at voice casting Every. Single. Time?

This is no slight on the actors, who I'm sure did what they were told... But it's about time we got a Thor who sounds like he should, and not like a character from Monty Python & the Holy Grail.

That little quibble aside, the Thor story was decent, and had a better resolution than the Wolverine story. The ending was a nice nod to older television endeavors, and the writing was worthy of a Thor comic.

Is this worth a purchase? Only if you're an animation superfan, a Marvel superfan, or a Wolverine superfan that needs every little thing made featuring these characters. Otherwise, I think it's entertaining to watch, but not something I'd rush to purchase. It is, after all, two 60-minute features (or less) that are pretty straightforward. There's not much twisting and turning in these plots, and that's fine. It's the nature of a Hulk story to be 70% action, and 30% plot. It's what you want, and expect, with a Hulk story.

I'd give it five stars if they had given the Asgardians the right voices. For me, it breaks the suspension of disbelief to hear some Asgardians sounding like Englishmen from upper-class London, and some sounding like women from Los Angeles. For you, that might not matter, though.

"HULK VS." is a 2-disc special edition featuring "Hulk vs. Wolverine" and "Hulk vs. Thor" animated movies. Released from Lionsgate there are numerous previews, various audio commentaries, and of course the actual movies.

Disc 1 contains "Hulk vs. Wolverine" (PG-13) and is 37 minutes long. Hulk is tearing up the Canadian country side and Wolverine is sent to stop him. The movie opens with Hulk and Wolverine battling. After the title and credit sequence the movie goes back to four hour earlier when Wolverine was brought in by helicopter to the small town of Elkford that was destroyed by Hulk. The Canadian military wants Wolverine to stop Hulk. If he can't be stopped then Wolverine is to kill him before he harms another town or city. The chase is on with Wolverine finding a lot more than expected including other foes in the Canadian wildness.

Disc 1 also contains audio commentaries with Craig Kyle, Chris Yost, Frank Paur, Kevin Altieri and Butch Lukic. There is also a first look at "Wolverine And The X-Men" coming in April along with a making of "Hulk vs. Wolverine" feature. There is also a feature about the "Hulk vs. Wolverine" world premiere at the San Diego Comic Con last year and a question and answer deal there at the convention.

The 45 minute Disc 2 features "Hulk vs. Thor" (PG-13) and is the story of Loki trying to destroy his stepbrother, Thor. The movie opens with another colorful credit sequence before taking us to the realm of the eternal: Asgard. Long ruled and protected by Odin all is well and the cycle continues. Every winter Odin must sleep and leaves things unprotected for seven days and that is when the wicked come. Thor leads the defense against the siege of darkness. Dr. Banner is spirited in by Loki so that he can be forced to become the Hulk and used to finally destroy, Thor. But, Hulk is not a weapon that can be controlled for long and the repercussions for all will be epic.

This disc also features audio commentary with Craig Kyle, Chris Yost, Frank Paur, Sam Liu and James Peters. Like the much bloodier and brutal "Hulk vs. Wolverine" disc, this disc also has a making of the feature and a first look feature at the next movie in the series. This one is on "Thor: Tales of Asgard" coming out on DVD this fall.  There is also a feature on Jack Kirby and his artwork with Thor.

The result is two very different movies that continue the legendary Marvel characters while providing plenty of back story. The animation is detailed as are the complicated story lines creating a viewing experience sure to please old and young alike.

Very well pleased with Marvel's latest animated feature; only complaint being the simplicity of much of the art (Sabertooth's face was especially simplified down) and animation, which could have been much more lavish.  Loved the lenticular slip-case cover.

Good development of Asgard in the Hulk Vs. Thor segment.  Some notions of Norse mythology are included, such as the resting Odin with one eye, the ravens that defend him, the relationship between Loki and Hela (tho her brother, the Fenris Wolf, resting next to her feet while she sits on her throne, is not mentioned).  We see Kirby and Simonson villains in the great battle against Asgard.  We do not, however, see Ulik the Troll, who, as Kirby drew him, was almost as formidable as the Hulk.

I have a problem with the metamorphosis of The Hulk thru the years.  When I first started reading comics in the mid 1960s, the Thor Vs. Hulk battle was one of the first I encountered.  There, The Hulk was only a little larger than Thor and they seemed pretty evenly matched.  Here The Hulk is almost 12 feet tall and a bit more than a match for Thor.

I had a lot of anticipation for this animated feature from Marvel when I first heard about it from the Next Avengers DVD, and it didn't let me down.

Hulk vs. Wolverine is almost right out of the classic comic that first introduced everybody's favorite Canadian antihero. The story starts off simple enough, Hulk's on a rampage and it's up to Logan to stop him. Only problem is the Weapon-X program gets involved. This feature is almost more of a Wolverine Origin story, but in the end it's Hulk, Logan, and the Weapon-X program in a massive brawl with every man and woman for themself! The animation is actually more simplistic looking then recent Marvel animated features. It almost looks more like the animated DC universe at times. But this is quickly made up for by the over-the-top action sequences. What's more is The Hulk and Wolverine don't pull their punches at all in this one. They smash, slash, crush, and carve each other up like they mean it, which is long overdue.

Hulk vs. Thor is, as the preview from Next Avengers said, more like Hulk vs. Asgard. The big green war machine takes on the land of the Gods while Odin sleeps, and it's up to Thor to stop him. Thor and Hulk have had a number of great fights over the years, and an animated feature dedicated to their rivalry was long overdue. The animation is actually a step up from Hulk vs. Wolverine, though still very stylized. The action is just as good though. Hulk smashes like their no tomorrow, and Thor does what he does best, fight monsters!

Both films are great additions to the Marvel Animated collection, and with a new X-men series on the way and an animated Thor special later this year, it looks like we'll have to make more room on the shelves.
Great Movie...I was not into Thor but after this viewing. I might pick put some Thor.

The best animated Marvel comics movie to date. Hulk vs Wolverine is the best of the two offerings. It's non-stop action from start to stop. Be advised that both movies are rated PG-13 and while not overly graphic, there are severed limbs and deaths.

Hulk vs Thor is fine, but after watching the green monster fight Wolverine and others, I was disappointed with the action.

Overall, the blu-ray version has great picture and sound quality and Hulk vs Wolverine is worth the full price alone.

In my opinion, Hulk Vs. has to be Marvel Animation's crowning achievement, thus far. After 5 great direct-to-DVD features, it finally gives us (not one but two) features with the right amount of exciting comic-book storytelling, thrilling action and cutting-edge animation to bring every comic fan's dream to the small screen. This 2-disc DVD set features 'twice the carnage' with Hulk Vs. Wolverine and Hulk Vs. Thor.

Disc 1:Hulk Vs. Wolverine. This feature starts off with the two battling from the very beginning. You soon find out that The Hulk has been leaving a path of destruction all over the canadian countryside and he needs to be stopped at all costs. So, the government calls in the only man that can truly take on the green giant: Wolverine. That leads us back to the battle. Yet, members of the Weapon X program(Deadpool, Omega Red, Sabretooth, and Lady Deathstrike) are pursuing The Hulk as a means of turning him into a weapon(not only to destroy Wolverine but to use to their benefit). That's when things get nasty. The remainder of the feature has The Hulk & Wolverine battling them instead of each other, actually. Bonus features include:Audio Commentary, three featurettes(including a first look at Wolverine & The X-Men) and a trailer gallery. While the story was alright and it had its' moments, I still loved it. Seeing Hulk and Wolverine square off(at least, a little bit) was well worth it.

Disc 2:Hulk Vs. Thor. While Odin(Asgard's protector and ruler) is taking his winter slumber, Loki(Thor's evil stepbrother) decides to sieze the opportunity to bring Thor and Asgard to their knees by bringing The Hulk to Asgard. With the help of The Enchantress, Loki separates Bruce Banner from The Hulk and takes control of The Hulk's functions attempting to storm the kingdom. However, The Hulk isn't so easily controlled and he's soon creating chaos all his own. Loki soon realizes that his only recourse is to reunite The Hulk with Bruce Banner. Only Bruce is in Hela's Realm(or Hell, as I'm taking it) and it takes Loki and Thor both to bring them both back together to stop the Hulk from bringing Ragnarok down on Asgard and bringing about the end of days for the godly paradise. Bonus features here include:Audio Commentary, several featurettes, a first look at "Thor:Tales of Asgard" and a trailer gallery as well. You'll notice there is a different look to this feature. Hulk himself has longer hair, thicker limbs and a bigger body. I like this as it stands as its' own feature, even though it is part of a larger one. Overall, I loved this feature better(and I hate to admit it but I've never been a fan of Thor). It has a more epic feel to it and feels more cohesive in its' plot. There's more characters from Thor's universe here as well so it doesn't just center around the two.

You can tell Marvel Animation loves The Hulk as he has been in 4 of 6 of their animated efforts.

I really loved this Special Edition DVD set and look forward to Marvel Animation's coming projects. Here's hoping that they continue the VS. series in some way. I'd love to see The Hulk go up against some of Marvel's other characters(like The Thing, Wendigo, or Red/Grey Hulk).

Well, it looks like Marvel has finally hit it's animation groove. After some solid 90's series, Marvel fell way behind while DC came out with a blitz of top-notch cartoons like Batman - The Animated Series and Justice League that easily blew away the competition. Straight to video releases from both comic giant have failed to be extraordinary. That seems to have changed at least on Marvel's end. The glut of recent animated works that match the quality of blockbusters like Iron Man has this geek foaming at the mouth. It seems as though Marvel has finally stopped trying to appease the masses and is giving the fans what they want. And what we want is quality animation written by comic book writers and produced by genuine comic book geeks. "Hulk Vs" consists of two (around) 40 minute films intended for hardcore fans that packs tons of action, creative direction, top-of-the-line voice acting, flawless representations of classic characters, and doesn't skimp on the violence either. There are tons of references and homages to classic moments from the comics that are sure to please as well. This is what I want to see when I watch an animated comic book adaptation. End of story. The two discs in this set are divided one film plus bonus features for each DVD. First up: Wolverine. This is far and away the best of the two. The true title should be "Wolverine Is A Total Bada$z With The Coolest Villains And Plus He Fights The Hulk". Logan is sent in to take down The Hulk dead or alive. "Sounds like fun" is his reply. The first encounter between the two icons is violent, bloody, and just plain sweet. I'm talking knock-down, drag-out, stab a motherfudger in the heart, leap onto his back using adamantium claws to dig in and stabilize yourself, bashing somebody into the ground and keep on pounding, dislocated joints, blood everywhere, and the whole whammy. Hard frickin' core. And that's all before the bad guys show up. Sabretooth ring a bell? How about Omega Red? Cool, right? add a truly psychotic Lady Deathstrike to that mix. Oh, and did I mention the animated debut of DEADPOOL, my very favorite character in all of comicdom?! This guy makes this film for me even more than the awesome action scenes. He is the Merc with the Mouth and he's exactly as he should be; wise-cracking, gun-blasting, trash-talking, and a$z-kicking. If you don't laugh at him struggling to piece together his trisected arm (healing factor) while pitched battle rages around him you are a sad, sad person. This is at least one fanboy's dream come true. Other moments of note include Hulk's battle with Deathstrike (doesn't end so well for the cyborg assassin; you will wince) and the look on Sabretooth's face when he turns to see an especially angry Hulk bearing down on him full-tilt. 5 stars, easy. And don't skip out on the credits, either. The second disc is not nearly as amazing, but still geektacular and a first in that it takes place entirely in Asgard, home of the gods. Here, the Allfather Odin sleeps his periodical slumber during which all of the evil hordes of the realm unleash their full might to attempt to take the kingdom while the king of the gods cannot defend it. That's where our hero comes in, the God of Thunder himself, Thor Odinson. Having sent the forces of evil packing yet again, the heroes of Asgard prepare for some rest and await Odin's awakening. But Thor's evil half-brother Loki has one more trick up his sleeve. Combining his own magic with Enchantress's, he is able to bring Bruce Banner to Asgard, separate him from The Hulk, and place Big Green under his direct control. This is not really "Hulk Vs Thor" This is "Hulk Vs. Asgard". Thor Odinson, verily thy might fared thee not well against the green behemoth's Fedoresque ground-and-pound. This is awesome if you're a Hulk fan, and not so much if you are a Thor fan. Come on, the dude's a GOD. Only cosmic entities should have near the juice to send him to death's door. But hey, minor complaint. We all know that these head-to-heads are little more than popularity contests anyways. Soon, Hulk breaks Loki's control and then he is everybody's problem. Too bad the God of Mischief sent Banner to the underworld. Now nobody can rein the monster in. Not Volstagg, nor Fandral, Hogun, and Balder, not Sif and Enchantress put together or Asgard's entire army, not one Frost Giant and not two. HULK SMASH EVERYONE! Very cool, but more emphasis on Thor's power would have served the fans much better. 4 stars Two animated comic book movies done right, one great price. Don't be a dope; if you have any interest in comics whatsoever, buy it. Special features include outstanding making-of featurettes for both, multiple commentaries for both, a tribute to Jack Kirby's groundbreaking work on the Thor comic, interviews and footage from the Comic-con premier of "Hulk Vs. Wolverine", and special looks at an upcoming animated Thor project and "Wolverine and the X-Men" which having seen the first 3 episodes I can safely say is the most exciting adaptation of the mutant superhero team yet. Every single one of these special features is well worth your time. This all adds up to my idea of a perfect set. 4 1/2 stars with bonus points for exceptional special features for a well-earned 5 stars. Keep the quality coming!

Okay, first let me state I love almost all things comic book.  I read comics religeously when I was younger right up until about the time I turned 14 or so.  Around that time I got interested in filmmaking and videography and theatre.  I was always able to draw and design graphically so there was always a possibility that comics was a field for me to go into, but then filmmaking consumed my being.  Anyway, I tell you all this because I want to make clear that I can't stand fan-boys(those annoying little gnats who didn't like Spider-Man simply because his web-shooters were changed to being biological as opposed to made by him) and I haven't read a comic since the 90's.  I do love comic book movies, and am very happy they are practically a genre by themselves at this point, but I want a satisfying film experience, and not random crap that has nothing to do with the movie's arch, plot or character development just because comic nerds will have a joygasmn over it.  Movies are not books, they're not comics, they're not tv shows.  They're their own beast and create a whole other universe for familar and unfamilar characters alike to exist.

Okay, now onto Hulk VS.  This is purely for comic book nerds and fans.  There are very little backstories or character development momemts, why would there be, the fans already know all there is to know about the characters.  Luckily, the animation is so vivid and fun you can easily be dazzled and enjoy it. I'm shocked the studio allowed this one to be made its so specific, but I like it.  It's ballsy to do something like that.  Hell, it still surprises how Kevin Smith was able make 6 films that were simply for a very specific group of fans and they were all loaded with obscure references and in-jokes.

Marvel Animation is hitting its stride and this, so far, is their crowning achievement.  They started getting good with Dr. Strange.  The animation was more alive and the storytelling more interesting.  Ultimate Avengers was pretty good, but the sequel was a little lackluster and boring.  Iron-Man was just dull and the CGI animaton didn't look good with the cell stuff.  Didn't see the Next Avengers, sorry but the idea of it just didn't appeal to me at all.

HULK VS. THOR
This is the best of the two, and I've never read a Thor comic beyond The Ultimate Avengers.  It had character development and actual drama. I just had the opportunity to check out the new Marvel/Lionsgate direct-to-dvd animated film, "Hulk Vs." and was pretty pleased overall.

First off, unlike previous entries in the Marvel animated films, this one is NOT a regular feature-length presentation.  It instead consists of two separate and unrelated stories.  The artwork was either pretty darned good (Thor) or excellent (Wolverine).  The animation itself is extremely good.  The previews on the disc are for the new animated series "Wolverine and the X-Men" and the next animated dvd movie "Thor: Tales of Asgard", which looks brilliant and is due in September.

"Hulk Vs. Wolverine" was the feature I enjoyed best but it had its weaknesses.  Its strengths are the characterization, the art and animation, and the beuatiful background paintings of the Canadian wilderness.  The weaknesses are that if you happen to be a casual viewer and are not familiar with the backstories of Wolverine and the Weapon X program, you will become lost very quickly.  There are a series of flashbacks that I felt were porly integrated into the story.  It was a little unclear (especially for casual viewers) that these were actually flashbacks and not occuring in real-time, thus causing a bit of confusion.  Also, to truly appreciate the villains (Sabretooth, Deadpool, Omega Red, and Lady Deathstrike), one needs to be familiar with them and their personalities from the comic books.  The action itself is brutal, violent, and non-stop--a hardcore beatdown that comic fans will love!

"Hulk Vs. Thor" was also quite good, but I simply didn't enjoy it quite as much.  The animation, artwork, and characterizartion were all excellent, though.  I think my reaction is based on my own personal preference for darker material, which "Hulk Vs. Wolverine" dafinitely catered to.  In the Thor story, Asgard is (as it should be) bright, gleaming, and beautiful.  Again, the action is quite good, although not as brutal as in the previous tale.  Fans of the Marvel take on Norse mythology will be quite pleased as lots of mythical figures are featured and various realms of Asgard are visited.  Magic, myth, and even a bit of romance dominate this tale and the Hulk is as dangerous as ever, even against immortals.

I watched this with my wife, who has enjoyed most of the previous superhero movies, animated or otherwise.  The difference is that I am a comic fan who is familiar with the characters and their backstories and she is not.  So from an objective point of view, I can say that the "Hulk Vs. Wolverine" story left her a bit confused and unsatisfied.  She enjoyed the Thor storyline far better as it isn't quite so dependent on knowing the characters and their backstories.  She is also a great fan of fantasy and mythology, so Thor was right up her alley.

Because of the brutal violence (which includes dismemberment) in the Wolverine story, I wouldn't recomend it for kids under 12.  I would be comfortable showing the Thor story to kids of 5 or older.  Of course, you should know your own children's ability to handle and process action and violence in a healthy way, so I'm just mentioning my own assesment.  Take it for what it's worth to you.

Keep the excellent animated movies coming, Marvel!  Great job!

Cheers & enjoy!

Marvel's latest D-T-DVD, a double-feature pitting the Hulk against, respectively, Wolverine and Thor; each is about the length of an animated series two-parter (around 40 minutes apiece), except (particularly in the case of the Wolverine one) much more violent.

Generally, I've not found Marvel's D-T-DVD stuff released so far to be that impressive, but these both really worked, in terms of what they set out to do.

Starting out, I'd say that the Hulk is really just kind of there in both stories; he's worked into the plot, but in both cases the writers basically hijacked the initial idea (Hulk vs. Wolverine, Hulk vs. Thor) to tell some other story. In Wolverine it's "finally, we get to do an R-rated version of Weapon X", and in Thor it's "finally, we get to cram in absolutely every aspect of the Thor mythos that we have any interest in onto animation" (which, given that there's both an animated series and a second D-T-DVD which is trailed here, may have been a bit unnecessary, but it's still good).

Part I:  Hulk vs. Wolverine

Basically a big fight scene. Wolverine is called in by Department H to deal with a rampaging Hulk, who has seemingly destroyed an entire town along the US-Canadian border. Wolverine tracks the Hulk down (not really knowing what he is at this point), fights him, and basically fights to a draw (this is the 70s-era version that Wolverine was created to fight), and then are captured by Weapon X (which apparently isn't associated with Department H here). This story is tied into the Wolverine and the X-Men cartoon, so Wolverine, Banner, Sabretooth, and Professor Thornton all have the same voice actors; also here are Lady Deathstrike, Omega Red, and Deadpool. Thornton wants Wolverine back in the program, but Deathstrike and Sabretooth would rather kill him, so they stab Thornton and, well, try to kill him. Big fight, etc. The attraction here is seeing "claw people" (as Hulk calls them) stab each other a lot with blood and stuff; Deadpool's quite funny.

Part II:  Hulk vs. Thor

Starting out, I'll say that fans of Thor who were expecting an epic throwdown between the two will be disappointed here; this might more accurately be titled "Hulk walks all over Thor, and so Thor has to find some other way of stopping the Hulk". I personally have never found the uber-godmoder Hulk all that interesting, but it's an established thing, so there you go; getting past that, the story's pretty good, and if you like Thor's world pretty everybody is here.

The story takes place during the yearly Odinsleep, when the All-Father rests and all the villains try to conquer Asgard because Odin is absurdly powerful and they've only got a chance when he's not there. Thor and co. beat up all comers, as usual (Thor's getting rather depressed by this endless cycle). Loki and Enchantress capture Bruce Banner, and turn him into the Hulk; Amora then pulls Banner out the Hulk (and Loki kills him), leaving only the incarnate rage (see Hulk #300 in the early 80s), with Loki pulling the strings. However, the rage becomes too much and breaks Loki's control, and Rage-Hulk is loosed and starts destroying everything. He beats up the Warriors Three and Balder, then pummels Thor to death (to Loki's delight), and heads off towards the city; Hela is about to claim Thor's soul, but Enchantress intervenes and brings him back to life, since her whole motivation for helping Loki was she was angry that Thor chose Sif over her. Thor and Enchantress capture Loki, and Thor makes Loki go with him to Hel to reclaim Banner to put him back in the Hulk, and sends Enchantress to help Sif, who's the End Boss guarding Odin. So Thor and Loki journey thither, while Hulk punches his way through like a bajillion random guards, Brunnhilde and the other Valkyries, etc. on his way there.

As a tour of the Nine Worlds, it packs quite a lot into 40+ minutes (it's the longer of the two); both of these stories just drop you into an established world, which is refreshingly different from how a lot of these films do things; you pick up all the necessary information as you go along.

All in all, it's a good package; less character or plot than big fights, but the short lengths of each piece means that they don't overstay their welcomes.

I was skeptical when I heard that Marvel was releasing another animated feature, but seeing as it involved the Hulk going up against two of my favorite Marvel characters, I gave it the benefit of the doubt.

And it didn't disappoint.

I highly recommend this DVD for any Marvel fan looking for a fun viewing experience.

I have to totally agree.  The Hulk vs. Wolverine is too short.  I am a huge Wolverine fan, and the action and story line were well received by me, but it could've gone on longer.  Didn't watch the Hulk vs. Thor yet.  Not really a Thor fan.

As a superhero fan, I was going to watch this regardless, but after the lackluster animated releases Marvel has put out so far, I didn't have my expectations set too high.

However, Hulk Vs. is by far the best animated Marvel film yet.  I think the fact that they split them up into 2 approx. half hour shorts helped tremendously, keeping the plot moving and the action tight.  Both episodes felt like they could've easily been a stand-alone issue of a comic book, with all the heroes keeping in character.

Hulk Vs. Wolverine is the standout, and sets a new standard in brutal cartoon violence (for a PG-13 rating of course).  We are treated to some great Wolverine back-story, right out of the Weapon X storyline, some hardcore Wolverine vs. Hulk fighting (which seemed like a combo of Wolverine's first appearance in the Hulk comic and the more recent Ultimate Hulk vs. Wolverine mini-series) and some great appearances by fan-favorite villains like Sabretooth, Omega Red, Lady Deathstrike, and Deadpool.

Hulk Vs. Thor was surprisingly entertaining, but being as I'm not that much of a Thor fan, I enjoyed the Wolverine story more.  That's not to say this wasn't a good episode, and I ultimately enjoyed it more than I expected.  Both films had excellent animation and fantastic voice-work.  Good writing, all by people who were obvious fans of the core material.

I highly recommend Hulk Vs.  It's two great stand-alone episodes that seem like they could be part of a larger universe.  Hopefully Marvel realizes this and begins adapting popular comic book arcs like Secret Invasion, Secret War, or Spider-Man Reign...
